instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
Liquid damage

Light one charger, no fan spin.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.56V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 12.58V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 12.58V

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.48V

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.33V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.03V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.33V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0V

And I am lost now….

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0V"
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> missing too?
Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and the 4 RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
If you aren´t using a 85watt original adapter you won´t get the <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>. That happened to me until I changed the PSU cable to a original 85 watt. And I understand that if you don´t have that voltage you wont be able to activate the PCH.
see if this can help you:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.it-tech.com.au/mac-q-a/pm-slp-s4-l-timing/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
Just to confirm I got genuine 85W charger.
Tried three chargers and got same voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32V"
Then you MUST have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> too; check that again.
If not present, check for short and post <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR>/20 voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
Not present :(
No short

<TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR> - 0V on all pins

<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>/3 - 3V 
<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>/7 - 3.3V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR>/1 - 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message: Do you get at least pulsing <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> when connect charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> light on charger, no fan spin
threads.message:
That is not a confirmation 100%.
You should get higher pulse.
Only an o-scope can catch the real peak pulse.
<SIGNAL>PM_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> should go high at same time.
